thread.title: JB Hi-Fi confident of more growth as it moves into the kitchen with home appliances
thread.title_full: JB Hi-Fi confident of more growth as it moves into the kitchen with home appliances

title: JB Hi-Fi confident of more growth as it moves into the kitchen with home appliances
text:
The retailer plans to open five new HOME stores in Australia and one JB Hi-Fi store in New Zealand over the next year.
Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi expects its sales and profit to continue to grow next year as it moves from living rooms into kitchens and laundries by turning its focus to home appliances.
Total sales grew by 4.8 per cent to $3.65 billion last financial year, with same-store sales in Australia up by 3.1 per cent, driven by smartphones, computers, fitness products and home appliances.
Those products offset a fall in software sales, down 9.7 per cent, while total sales in New Zealand were down 0.1 per cent and same-store sales down 4.5 per cent.
JB Hi-Fi is banking on its expansion into home appliances. Photo: Glenn Hunt
Net profit grew by 6.3 per cent to $136.5 million, higher than the company's $127 million-to-$131 million guidance.
Advertisement JB Hi-Fi chief executive Richard Murray said trade in June was especially strong due to the instant tax write-off for small businesses announced in May, with total sales climbing 7.6 per cent in that month, compared to a 5.5 per cent drop in the same month last year.
Mr Murray said he expected sales to grow another 5.4 per cent to $3.85 billion in 2016 by opening six new stores and converting 16 existing stores to JB Hi-Fi HOME outlets, which sell home and kitchen appliances.
Confident: JB Hi-Fi chief executive Richard Murray. Photo: Patrick Scala
He said small home appliances like toasters and irons had been rolled out to four standard JB Hi-Fi stores with "pleasing results" and they would be in another 14 stores by November.
"The rollout of small appliances into our existing store network is a natural progressions of our proven HOME appliances strategy," he said.
"In the long term, we expect most stores to stock home appliances with the range ... tailored to suit each specific store."
JB Hi-Fi will have an edge over big box rivals Harvey Norman and the Good Guys by selling small appliances in shopping centres that they cannot access, while Dick Smith plans to introduce small appliances to 100 stores over the next five months.
Chief financial officer Nick Wells said about 90 square metres of floor space would be turned over to appliances in existing stores, compared to about 135 square metres in HOME stores, but Mr Murray insisted this would not come at the expense of struggling categories like software.
"We are not prepared to accept any increased decline in software as a result of rolling out home appliances," he said, adding that space would be used more efficiently.
Mr Murray said he was looking forward to this year's important Christmas trade and expected sales to be supported by new tech products.
"Fitness, the whole watch category and things around your personal ecosystem – be it Fitbit, be it Garmin – there are plenty of products where the growth we're still seeing is very strong and it'll be another strong Christmas," he said.
"We've got plenty of established brands with plenty of innovation. It's not uncommon to see new phones released prior to Christmas … I see some things that we're going to have that we didn't have last Christmas that are exciting."
The retailer plans to open five new HOME stores in Australia and one JB Hi-Fi store in New Zealand over the next year, bringing the total number of stores to 214, and also convert 16 existing stores to HOME outlets, bringing the total number to 75.
The most recent ANZ-Roy Morgan consumer confidence survey, released weekly, showed a confidence rating of 112.9, exceeding the long-term August average of 109.9.
JB Hi-Fi releases its results earlier than many other companies and is seen as a bellwether for retailers in the reporting season.
